a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:31): OK, I think we can take discussion about it to the list. But I will bring it up with Sam and Chris directly as well.
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:33): The pain of organising complex hierarchies in CVS sounds like it could be greater than the pain of switching to a not-yet-supported VCS

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:35): (particularly since DVCSs seem to make it relatively non-painful to work without a centralised repository, so it'd be alright at first even if the W3C couldn't actually host the files itself)
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:35): something like using git for a masster copy which committed to cvs whenever it was updated would probably make life easier
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:36): fwiw, the team well understands that there are better version-control systems that CVS, and the plan is not to stay with the CVS forever
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:36): in the mean time, we need to work within the limitations of what we have at hand
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:37): Do our limitations have to include relying on the W3C's facilities?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:37): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: no, not necessarily
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:37): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f's suggestion about using git and pushing the commits to CVS would be fine by me
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:38): remembers seeing lots of XHTML2 stuff on aptest.com, so it doesn't seem that uncommon to rely on external services
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:38): That sounds reasonable to me
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:39): though is it worth pushing the commits to CVS, rather than just uploading them as static files into a web server directory somewhere?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:40): that's a fair point
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:41): I guess static copies would work fine, though I can imagine some people might be happy to have them available in CVS too
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:41): Maybe it would be worthwhile just so people who don't understand git could do "cvs up; edit some test file; cvs diff > patch-to-send-to-mailing-list"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): I will say that one advantage of just using CVS would be that it's a lower barrier of entry for potential contributors
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:42): in that there are more people who easy access/setup for CVS client tools than for git
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:43): I'm not so sure that's quite so true these days
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:43): though I guess in companies it might be
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:43): e.g. Windows has git with a GUI these days

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:43): I do have to say that I can see git or some other distributed VCS being much more valuable for projects where you need to do a lot of branching and merging, and need to do it quickly and easily
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:44): and 'git clone branch; edit some test files; git diff > patch' is not more complex than cvs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:44): true

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:45): It's not more complex but it's different, and people already understand cvs and have it installed, so it's at least twice as much work if they have to have git too
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:45): well, I don't see there'd be any problem having a cvs mirror around
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:46): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: anyway, this is exactly why we need a test czar
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:46): some people will object to whatever ends up getting decided
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:47): and in the end, the choice of VCS and directory structure is not critical to the success of the work
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:48): isn't sure that's necessarily true
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:48): The success of the work is dependent on volunteers contributing to the work, and that is strongly dependent on how easy it is to contribute

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:48): so it's more important that whatever choice is made is what makes it easiest for the person(s) leading and actually doing the work to manage it in the way that works best for them

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:49): and issues like VCS can have a fairly significant effect on how easy it is to contribute, and how much time and effort you have to waste trying to get all the latest versions and create patches and review things without getting lost
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:50): would agree that it makes sense for decisions to be made only by the people who will be directly affected by those decisions
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:51): The problem is everybody has different opinions about what constitutes "easiest".
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:52): You can solve that problem by beating up everyone who is wrong
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:52): that's only a problem if you consider everyone's opinion but your own to be equally valid
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:52): Fortunately, we can migrate among VCS systems later as needed (if people directly involved in the work decide they want to)
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:52): well, from my experience running an open-source game, I would say that the VCS choice is not all that big a deal these days
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:53): people who want to contribute to things will go to reasonable effort to do so
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:53): right
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:54): and there is definitely at least one DVCS which is easily obtainable on all of {Windows, OS X, Unix}

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:54): 's experience from a not-quite-open-source game is that it is a big deal, because the artists have learnt how to use TortoiseSVN and won't understand anything else :-)
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:55): there's TortoiseDarcs and TortoiseGit and TortoiseTheMoonOnAStick these days
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:56): Are they anything like TortoiseCVS/TortoiseSVN, or are they just random GUIs with "Tortoise" stuck in front of their names?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:56): yeah, branched from the same code
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:56): so essentially the same interface
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:56): Do they still have a nice simple right click -> "update", right click -> "commit" model?
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:57): rather than the crazy checkout/pull/update/clone/branch/whatever model that the command-line tools tend to favour
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:58): also, we're dealing with people who are competent enough to write browser tests
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:59): (I think DVCS wouldn't work on my game anyway because there's 5GB of stuff in the repository and nobody is going to want to have a clone of it all :-( )

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:12): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: you make a good point -- it's hard imagine that somebody competent enough to write a browser test that will pass review will not be competent enough able to install and learn whatever VCS client they need
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:13): which reminds me: the other thing you'd need to decide on is how to handle review
